question: Question_04
statement:
Prove that

\begin{align*}P \Rightarrow ( Q \vee R ) \equiv ( P \Rightarrow Q ) \vee ( P \Rightarrow R).\end{align*}
sols:
Using \href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truth_table}{truth tables}.

We write the truth table for each of the two statements that we would
like to compare.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}lllll@{}}
\textbf{P} & \textbf{Q} & \textbf{R} & \textbf{Q $\vee$ R} & \textbf{P
$\rightarrow$ (Q $\vee$ R)}\\

T & T & T & T & T\\
T & T & F & Â~T & T\\
T & F & T & T & T\\
T & F & F & F & F\\
F & T & T & T & T\\
F & T & F & T & T\\
F & F & T & T & T\\
F & F & F & F & T\\\\
\caption{table for \textbf{P $\rightarrow$ (Q $\vee$ R)}}
\end{longtable}

And

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllll@{}}
\textbf{P} & \textbf{Q} & \textbf{R} & \textbf{P $\rightarrow$ Q} &
\textbf{P $\rightarrow$ R} & \textbf{(P $\rightarrow$ Q) $\vee$ (P
$\rightarrow$ R)}\\

T & T & T & T & T & T\\
T & T & F & T & F & T\\
T & F & T & F & T & T\\
T & F & F & F & F & F\\
F & T & T & Â~T & T & T\\
F & T & F & T & T & T\\
F & F & T & T & T & T\\
F & F & F & T & T & T\\\\
\caption{table for \textbf{(P $\rightarrow$ Q) $\vee$ (P $\rightarrow$
R)}}
\end{longtable}

Since the last column is the same for both tables (and since we order
the truth of \emph{P}, \emph{Q} and \emph{R} in the same order) we can
conclude that the two statements are logically equivalent.

Another solution consists of using an equivalent statement for the
implication:

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B \equiv \lnot A \lor B\end{align*}

So the statement

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
P \Rightarrow ( Q \lor R ) \equiv ( P \Rightarrow Q ) \lor ( P \Rightarrow R)\end{align*}
becomes

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\lnot P \lor ( Q \lor R )) \equiv ( \lnot P \lor Q ) \lor ( \lnot P \lor R)\end{align*}

To prove this statement, we'll just show that the left hand side (LHS)
is equal to the right hand side (RHS).

For the LHS, we get

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
\lnot P \lor ( Q \lor R )) \equiv \lnot P \lor Q \lor R\end{align*} since
disjunction (the logical OR) is associative (that means doesn't care
about brackets).

For the RHS we get

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
( \lnot P \lor Q ) \lor ( \lnot P \lor R) \equiv \lnot P \lor Q \lor R\end{align*}
since again the disjunction is associative and having twice the Â¬P term
is useless.

We obtained that LHS = RHS which proves the statement.
